PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ DihedralGroup.isCyclic_iff`
`+ DihedralGroup.not_isCyclic`
`+ IsCyclic.commutative`
`+ commutative_iff`
`+ not_commutative`
`+ val_two_eq_two_mod`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
~~I also wonder if we should deprecate `IsCyclic.commGroup` since `IsCyclic.commutative` should suffice and has the advantage of being a `Prop`.~~ Never mind, it might be useful.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12873057209/job/35889821459)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12873057209/job/35889821749)
I'm working on a split at this PR: #20894

Thanks!

maintainer delegate

```suggestion
    Std.Commutative (Â· * Â· : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Î±) where
  comm x y :=
    let âŸ¨_, hgâŸ© := IsCyclic.exists_generator (Î± := Î±)
    let âŸ¨_, hxâŸ© := hg x
    let âŸ¨_, hyâŸ© := hg y
    hy â–¸ hx â–¸ zpow_mul_comm _ _ _
```

```suggestion
lemma not_commutative_of_two_lt {n : â„•} (h : 2 < n) :
```

Why don't you merge those into a single lemma assuming `n â‰  1`, `n â‰  2`? Something
```suggestion
lemma not_commutative : âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n â‰  1 â†’ n â‰  2 â†’
    Â¬Std.Commutative fun (x y : DihedralGroup n) => x * y
  | 0, _, _ => by
    rintro âŸ¨h'âŸ©
    specialize h' (r 1) (sr 0)
    simp at h'
  | n + 3, _, _ => by
    rintro âŸ¨h'âŸ©
    specialize h' (r 1) (sr 0)
    rw [r_mul_sr, zero_sub, sr_mul_r, zero_add, sr.injEq, neg_eq_iff_add_eq_zero, one_add_one_eq_two,
      â† ZMod.val_eq_zero, ZMod.val_two_eq_two_mod] at h'
    exact Nat.not_le_of_gt h <| Nat.le_of_dvd Nat.zero_lt_two <| Nat.dvd_of_mod_eq_zero h'
```
and can you add an iff version as well?
Done!

nit:
```suggestion
    Std.Commutative (fun x y : DihedralGroup n â†¦ x * y) â†” n = 1 âˆ¨ n = 2 where
  mp := by contrapose!; rintro âŸ¨h1, h2âŸ©; exact not_commutative h1 h2
  mpr := by rintro (rfl | rfl) <;> exact âŸ¨by decideâŸ©
```
Aha! Thanks.
I think is is the wrong way around. Dihedral groups are more complicated than cyclic groups, so dihedral groups should import cyclic groups.

There is an `assert_not_exists TwoSidedIdeal` in Dihedral.lean that prevents Cyclic.lean from being imported. I didn't want to touch that.

I don't know which way around is better. But the dihedral groups are a concrete inductive construction and comparable to `ZMod` (which is imported in Cyclic.lean), whereas `IsCyclic` is a type class and in that sense more complicated.
Why are we importing `TwoSidedIdeal` in `GroupTheory.SpecificGroups.Cyclic`?! (~~currently investigating for myself~~ ran out of time)

It would be great to make sure `GroupTheory.SpecificGroups.Cyclic` doesn't import `TwoSidedIdeal`, and please investigate that if you have some time. For the purpose of this PR, it would be okay to comment out the `assert_not_exists`
I can have a look. But actually my opinion is that Cyclic.lean should import Dihedral.lean (as it does ZMod), not the other way round.
Yes, I agree. My opinion is that cyclic groups really shouldn't import two-sided ideals, but so shouldn't dihedral groups, so leaving that as further work (eg with a TODO) would be fine

So what I've found is if we just move `Int.quotientSpanNatEquivZMod`, `Int.quotientSpanEquivZMod`, and `ZMod.prodEquivPi` out of `Mathlib.Data.ZMod.Quotient`, then we can remove the import of ideals from that file.
Oh no, that still doesn't solve the problem in `Mathlib.GroupTheory.SpecificGroups.Cyclic`

> I don't know which way around is better. But the dihedral groups are a concrete inductive construction and comparable to `ZMod` (which is imported in Cyclic.lean), whereas `IsCyclic` is a type class and in that sense more complicated.

Dihedral groups are basically built out of cyclic groups. Indeed, the definition of `DihedralGroup` uses `ZMod` even though it doesn't directly mention `IsCyclic`. My feeling is that cyclic groups are the simplest of the specific groups, so it should be fine to import them into other specific group files so that you can say things like "this particular subgroup is cyclic".
Seems like there's a refactor that needs to be made, but it can wait for another PR.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(GroupTheory/SpecificGroups): dihedral groups are not cyclic (with one exception)

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
